dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Global Range: Known from Montgomery County, Maryland; Liberty and Wakulla Counties, Florida; Vermilion and Lafayette Parishes, Louisiana; and Macon County, North Carolina; also reported from China, Japan, and Korea (Crum and Anderson 1981).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObjects.title: NatureServe Conservation Status
dataObjects.description:
Rounded Global Status Rank: G3 - Vulnerable

Reasons: Taxiphyllum alternans grows on soil, humus, or bark at the base of trees in wet or swampy places. The moss is apparently quite rare in the Gulf Coast region, occurring in only two Louisiana parishes and two Florida counties. The species is also known from one North Carolina county, and from the bank of a canal opposite Plummers Island in Maryland. It has also been reported from Japan, Korea, and China.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.description: Comments: Forest management practices (harvest, site prep, Rx fire) present a moderate threat; human disturbance is a low-level threat (Southern Appalachian Species Viability Project 2002).
